head.title: Effects of Fatty Acid Compositions on Heavy Oligomer Formation and Catalyst Deactivation during Deoxygenation of Triglycerides | ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering

meta.content: Effects of Fatty Acid Compositions on Heavy Oligomer Formation and Catalyst Deactivation during Deoxygenation of Triglycerides

Deoxygenation of triglycerides (e.g., vegetable and microalgae oils) through hydro-upgrading is one of the most important routes to produce oxygen-free hydrocarbon fuels from biomass. Even though natural triglycerides are composed of fatty acids of different structures, their effects on catalytic selectivity and deactivation during deoxygenation have not been comprehensively investigated. In this study, we used three different reactant triglycerides including palm oil, soybean oil, and linseed oil for catalytic deoxygenation over Pt/γ-Al2O3. These oils consist of fatty acids with increasing degrees of unsaturation in the order of palm oil (number of C═C per fatty acid: 0.55) < soybean oil (1.33) < linseed oil (2.18). The catalytic results showed that the increased unsaturation of the triglycerides caused enhanced formation of heavy products by oligomerization (mostly dimers) of unsaturated fatty acid derivatives through Diels–Alder reaction and/or radical addition. These heavy products were readily transformed to coke species, causing catalyst deactivation. In this regard, we demonstrated that the prehydrogenation of triglycerides at a mild temperature is highly beneficial for steadily obtaining a high yield of diesel-range paraffins and retarding catalyst deactivation in deoxygenation.

div.p:
Deoxygenation of triglycerides (
e.g
., vegetable and microalgae oils) through hydro-upgrading is one of the most important routes to produce oxygen-free hydrocarbon fuels from biomass. Even though natural triglycerides are composed of fatty acids of different structures, their effects on catalytic selectivity and deactivation during deoxygenation have not been comprehensively investigated. In this study, we used three different reactant triglycerides including palm oil, soybean oil, and linseed oil for catalytic deoxygenation over Pt/γ-Al
2
O
3
. These oils consist of fatty acids with increasing degrees of unsaturation in the order of palm oil (number of C═C per fatty acid: 0.55) < soybean oil (1.33) < linseed oil (2.18). The catalytic results showed that the increased unsaturation of the triglycerides caused enhanced formation of heavy products by oligomerization (mostly dimers) of unsaturated fatty acid derivatives through Diels–Alder reaction and/or radical addition. These heavy products were readily transformed to coke species, causing catalyst deactivation. In this regard, we demonstrated that the prehydrogenation of triglycerides at a mild temperature is highly beneficial for steadily obtaining a high yield of diesel-range paraffins and retarding catalyst deactivation in deoxygenation.

div.span: KEYWORDS:

span.p: The effects of different fatty acid compositions on the catalytic selectivity and deactivation were investigated during triglyceride deoxygenation.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Extensive efforts have been made to develop processes for converting sustainable biomass resources to fuels and high-value chemicals.
(1−4)
Among biomass feedstocks, triglycerides (
e.g
., vegetable oil and microalgae oil) have been widely investigated for producing biofuels,
(3−5)
olefins,
(6,7)
and lube base oil.
(8,9)
Triglycerides are esters built with three fatty acids (typically C
14
–C
22
) and one glycerol. An important advantage of using triglycerides over other biomass feedstocks is their highly paraffinic structures with low oxygen contents, which can be readily upgraded to high-energy-density fuels via various catalytic conversions. Such catalytic processes include the production of biodiesel (
e.g
., fatty acid methyl esters) by transesterification,
(5,10−12)
and green diesel
(12−19)
and biojet fuel
(19−24)
production through hydro-upgrading.

Biodiesel production by transesterification of triglycerides with methanol or ethanol is currently the major process commercially used. However, oxygen-containing biodiesel is not fully compatible with conventional diesel engines and thus should be blended with petro-diesel or the engines have to be modified.
(25)
Furthermore, biodiesel has poor oxidative stability and cold-flow properties.
(26)
In contrast, deoxygenation of triglycerides by hydro-upgrading can produce oxygen-free hydrocarbons that can overcome the intrinsic problems of biodiesel.
(13,15−17,27)
The resultant hydrocarbons are fully compatible with conventional internal combustion engines. Catalytic deoxygenation of triglycerides produces
n
-paraffins that can be directly used as a diesel (often called “green diesel” to differentiate from oxygen-containing “biodiesel”). These hydrocarbons even outperform petroleum-derived fuels in terms of cetane numbers (85–99, compared with 45–55 for petro-diesel).
(18,26)
Alternatively, the resultant
n
-paraffins can be additionally hydrocracked into smaller branched hydrocarbons (typically C
8
–C
16
) that can be used as an aviation fuel (“bio-jet fuel”).
(19−24)

Deoxygenation of triglycerides can generally be carried out over supported metal catalysts such as Pd,
(13,14,21,27−29)
Pt,
(13−15,21,22,29)
Ni,
(13,14,29−33)
and MoS
2
-based catalysts (
e.g
., NiMoS
2
and CoMoS
2
)
(14−16,21,27,32)
under a hydrogen atmosphere. At the initial stage of the reaction, triglycerides containing unsaturated fatty acid units are generally hydrogenated and decomposed into three saturated fatty acids by hydrogenolysis (
Scheme 1
). The produced fatty acids are then deoxygenated by hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) and/or decarboxylation/decarbonylation (DCO).
(34,35)
The HDO pathway produces
n
-paraffins containing the same carbon number with those of the original fatty acids because the oxygens are removed as H
2
O. On the other hand, DCO produces
n
-paraffins containing one less carbon atom because the oxygens in the fatty acid units are removed as CO
x
. Minor amounts of oxygenates such as fatty acid, fatty alcohol, and fatty acid ester are known to be formed by incomplete deoxygenation.
(27,32,36,37)
Along with the production of bulky hydrocarbons, light hydrocarbons (C
1
–C
3
) are also coproduced due to the hydrogenolysis of the glycerol unit and methanation reaction.
Scheme 1. Reaction Pathways in the Deoxygenation of Triglycerides

In previous studies, most research efforts have been paid for understanding the effects of the catalyst compositions and reaction conditions to achieve increased deoxygenation activities. In those studies, model reactants (
e.g
., unnatural triglycerides,
(27,37,38)
fatty acids,
(27,35−40)
and fatty acid methyl esters
(38,41−44)
) containing only saturated fatty acid units (
e.g
., stearic,
(35,37−40,44)
palmitic,
(36,37,39)
and lauric acids
(36,37)
) have often been investigated. One possible reason is to simplify the analysis of products and/or to reduce the experimental difficulty of injecting viscous reactants into a reactor system. However, depending on their origin, natural triglycerides include various fatty acid units with different numbers of C═C bonds (or different degree of unsaturation). The presence of C═C bonds in the fatty acid units can lead to various side reactions and cause rapid catalyst deactivation. In a batch reactor, Murzin and colleagues showed that increased degree of unsaturation of feedstock resulted in the substantial formation of oligomers/aromatics and fast catalyst deactivation.
(45,46)
Thus, far, however, rather limited researches have been carried out to investigate the effects of triglyceride structures on product selectivity and catalytic deactivation during deoxygenation in a continuous fixed-bed reactor, which is industrially more relevant.

In the present work, we studied the effects of different fatty acid compositions of triglycerides on product selectivity and catalyst deactivation during deoxygenation in a continuous fixed-bed reactor. Vegetable oils with various unsaturation degrees (palm oil, soybean oil, and linseed oil) were deoxygenated over a Pt/γ-Al
2
O
3
catalyst. This study shows that increased unsaturation in triglycerides can substantially reduce the yield of the target
n
-paraffins by producing heavy byproducts such as oligomers of fatty acid derivatives and also cause fast catalyst deactivation due to coke formation. In this regard, we propose that presaturation of triglycerides at a mild reaction temperature is highly beneficial for the efficient and steady deoxygenation of triglycerides into diesel-range hydrocarbons.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
As a catalyst for hydro-upgrading, 1 wt % Pt/γ-Al
2
O
3
was prepared by wet impregnation of an aqueous solution of Pt(NH
3
)
4
(NO
3
)
2
onto γ-Al
2
O
3
.
(22)
After the impregnation, the sample was dried at 373 K for 12 h, followed by calcination at 673 K for 3 h in dry air. The sample was subsequently reduced under a H
2
flow at 673 K for 3 h.

Elemental analysis of the catalyst was performed using inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) with OPTIMA 7300 DV (PerkinElmer). N
2
adsorption–desorption isotherm was collected using BELSorp-max (BEL Japan) at 77 K after vacuum-degassing the catalyst at 473 K for 12 h. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) area was calculated in the
P
/
P
0
range of 0.10–0.30. H
2
chemisorption was measured at 323 K using ASAP 2020 (Micromeritics). Before measuring the isotherm, the catalyst was vacuum-degassed at 573 K for 6 h, reduced by H
2
at 673 K for 2 h, and then evacuated at 673 K for 2 h. The chemisorption amount was determined by extrapolating the linear regime (10–30 kPa) of the isotherm to zero pressure. The diameter of Pt cluster was estimated from the metal dispersion (H/Pt) using the equation:
(47)
(1)

High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images were collected using a FEI Talos F200X STEM at 200 kV, after mounting the catalyst on a Cu grid. More than 200 crystallites were counted to analyze the particle size distribution. The surface-area-weighted mean cluster diameter was calculated using the equation:
(47)
(2)

The amounts of Brønsted and Lewis acids were quantified with Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) after adsorption of pyridine as a base probe molecule. The FT-IR spectrum was measured with a Thermo Nicolet NEXUS spectrometer. Typically, 15 mg of the sample was pressed into a self-supporting wafer and then placed within an
in situ
IR cell having CaF
2
windows. After vacuum-degassing at 723 K for 4 h, a background spectrum was collected. Pyridine adsorption was performed at 423 K for 1 h using a room-temperature pyridine vapor source, followed by evacuation at the same temperature for 2 h to remove weakly physisorbed pyridine. The IR spectrum was collected with a resolution of 4.0 cm
–1
. The amounts of Brønsted and Lewis acids were analyzed using IR bands at 1545 cm
–1
(molar extinction coefficient: 1.67 cm μmol
–1
) and 1445 cm
–1
(2.22 cm μmol
–1
), respectively.
(48)
The amount of coke deposited in the used catalyst was quantified by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) under an air flow using Setaram TGA 92 (ramp: 5 K min
–1
).

div.h3: Analysis of the Fatty Acid Compositions in the Triglycerides
div.div:
In this study, palm oil (Sigma-Aldrich), soybean oil (Sigma), and linseed oil (Aldrich) were used as reactant triglycerides for catalytic deoxygenation. To analyze the fatty acid compositions of these triglycerides, transesterification with methanol was carried out to obtain fatty acid methyl esters, which were analyzed using gas chromatography (GC).
(11)
Typically, 1 g of the triglycerides was reacted with 4.5 g of methanol (methanol/triglyceride ratio ∼6) for 1 h at 338 K using 1 wt % NaOH as a catalyst. The upper phase of the product and methyl heptadecanoate (Sigma-Aldrich, 99%) as an internal standard were dissolved in chloroform, and then analyzed by GC (Agilent 7890) equipped with a flame ionization detector and HP-5 column (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.5 μm).

Single-step catalytic deoxygenation (
Scheme 2
a) was carried out in a stainless steel down-flow fixed-bed reactor (10.9 mm inner diameter). Typically, 2.4 g of 1 wt % Pt/γ-Al
2
O
3
catalyst (150–300 μm) was pretreated at 653 K under a H
2
flow for 3 h. Deoxygenation was carried out at 653 K by introducing the triglycerides at the rate of 2.4 g h
–1
with a HPLC pump (WHSV = 1.0 h
–1
). All of the tubings and the triglyceride container were carefully wrapped with heating tape (353 K) to inhibit the solidification of the triglycerides. The H
2
flow rate was 46 mL min
–1
and the total pressure was fixed at 20 bar using a back pressure regulator. The liquid products were collected using a liquid condenser preheated at 353 K and separated from condensed water by decanting. Then, the products and
n
-dodecane (Sigma-Aldrich, > 99%) as an internal standard were dissolved in chloroform and analyzed using GC. For the quantification of unconverted triglycerides, a high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) system (Agilent 1260 Infinity) with an evaporative light scattering detector and a Chromolith Performance-Si column (100 mm × 4.6 mm) was used.
(49)
The elemental compositions of the liquid products were analyzed using an elemental analyzer (Thermo scientific FLASH 2000). The effective hydrogen-to-carbon ratio (H/C
eff
) was estimated using the equation,
(3)
where
n
(H),
n
(O),
n
(N),
n
(S), and
n
(C) indicate the molar amounts of H, O, N, S, and C, respectively.
(4,50)
Scheme 2. Process Diagrams of (a) Single-Step and (b) Two-Step Deoxygenation

The yield of heavy products (undetectable either by GC or HPLC) was calculated by subtracting the yields of the GC-detectable products and glycerides from the yield of the total liquid products. To analyze the molecular size distributions of the heavy products, gel permeation chromatography (GPC) was carried out. The liquid products were dissolved in tetrahydrofuran (Daejung, HPLC grade) and analyzed using Agilent 1260 Infinity equipped with two PLgel 5 μm mixed-C (300 mm × 7.5 mm) columns and a refractive index (RI) detector. Heptadecane (Sigma-Aldrich, 99%), deoxygenated dimer acid, and palm oil were used as reference materials to assign the GPC peak positions. Deoxygenated dimer acid was prepared by catalytic deoxygenation of the commercially available dimer acid (Aldrich, average
M
n
∼ 570). Dimer acid dissolved in octane (30 wt %) was deoxygenated over a 1 wt % Pt/γ-Al
2
O
3
catalyst in similar conditions mentioned above (liquid injection rate of 2.4 g h
–1
; 653 K; H
2
flow rate of 46 mL min
–1
; 20 bar). From the collected liquid products, the octane solvent was removed using a rotary evaporator at 353 K. Elemental analysis confirmed that the oxygen content in the deoxygenated dimer acid was less than 0.7 wt % (dimer acid: 11.0 wt %), which indicated almost complete deoxygenation.

Two-step catalytic deoxygenation was carried out in two fixed-bed reactors connected sequentially (
Scheme 2
b). In both reactors, 2.4 g of 1 wt % Pt/γ-Al
2
O
3
catalyst (150–300 μm) was loaded and pretreated at 653 K under a H
2
flow for 3 h. In the first reactor, prehydrogenation of the triglycerides was carried out at a mild reaction temperature (473 K). In the second reactor, deoxygenation was carried out at 653 K as in the case of the aforementioned single-step deoxygenation. For the reaction, triglyceride was injected at a rate of 2.4 g h
–1
using a HPLC pump (WHSV = 1.0 h
–1
). The H
2
flow rate was 46 mL min
–1
, and the total pressure was fixed at 20 bar. Liquid products were collected and analyzed in the same way as for the single-step deoxygenation.

To estimate the deactivation rate of each reaction, the time-on-stream results were fitted with the power-law equation:
(51)
(4)
where
a
is the relative rate (defined as the paraffin yield at
t
divided by the initial paraffin yield at
t
= 0),
k
deac
is the deactivation rate constant, and
d
is the order of deactivation (
d
= 1, 2, and 3).
(51)

div.div:
As a catalyst for triglyceride deoxygenation, 1 wt % Pt was supported on a γ-Al
2
O
3
support, which had a BET surface area of 200 m
2
g
–1
and a pore volume of 0.46 mL g
–1
. ICP-AES analysis revealed that the Pt/γ-Al
2
O
3
catalyst contained 0.95 wt % Pt, which is very close to the nominal loading. The catalyst showed a H/Pt ratio of 1.0 in the H
2
chemisorption. This corresponded to the spherical Pt clusters having 1.13 nm diameter on average (
d
chem
).
(47)
The HAADF-STEM image (
Figure
1
a) showed the presence of highly dispersed Pt clusters on the γ-Al
2
O
3
support. The surface-area-weighted mean cluster diameter (
d
STEM
) was determined as 1.23 nm. The diameters of the Pt clusters determined both by H
2
chemisorption (
d
chem
) and HAADF-STEM (
d
STEM
) were highly consistent. The pyridine IR spectrum of the Pt/γ-Al
2
O
3
catalyst is shown in
Figure
1
b. The IR band at 1445 cm
–1
could be assigned to the coordinately bonded pyridine on the Lewis acid sites (170 μmol g
–1
). The absence of the IR band at 1545 cm
–1
indicated the absence of Brønsted acid sites.

div.h3: Fatty Acid Compositions of the Triglycerides
div.div:
Table
1
shows the fatty acid compositions of the palm oil, soybean oil, and linseed oil. The fatty acids are denoted by “Cα:β”, where α indicates the number of carbon atoms and β indicates the number of C═C bonds in the fatty acids. The analysis showed that all the triglycerides were mainly composed of C
16
and C
18
fatty acids. The average number of C═C bonds per fatty acid (or degree of unsaturation) increased in the order of palm oil (0.55) < soybean oil (1.33) < linseed oil (2.18).
Table 1. Fatty Acid Compositions of the Reactant Triglycerides

tr.td: Avg. # of double bonds in a fatty acid

div.div:
For the single-step deoxygenation, three different triglycerides (palm oil, soybean oil, and linseed oil) were hydrotreated over the Pt/γ-Al
2
O
3
catalyst in a fixed bed reactor (
Scheme 2
a). The product yields as a function of time-on-stream are plotted in
Figure
2
. The liquid products from all the triglycerides were mostly composed of saturated normal C
15
and C
17
paraffins during the early reaction period (4 h,
Table
2
). Considering that C
16
and C
18
fatty acids were the dominant components of all triglycerides, the major formations of C
15
and C
17
n
-paraffins with one less carbon implied that the oxygens in fatty acids were mostly removed by DCO (removal of oxygens by CO/CO
2
) rather than by HDO (removal of oxygens by H
2
O) (
Scheme 1
). This result is consistent with earlier studies showing that noble metal catalysts (Pt
(22,44)
and Pd
(14,27,28,52)
) prefer DCO over HDO. The conversion of all the triglycerides gave approximately an 80 wt % yield of liquid products compared to the original mass of the triglycerides (
Figure
2
). The yield was very similar to the theoretical paraffin yields (80.5, 81.6, and 82.2 wt % for the palm oil, soybean oil, and linseed oil, respectively), which were calculated assuming that the glycerol unit in the triglycerides is decomposed to light gaseous products (C
1
–C
3
) and the fatty acids units are mainly deoxygenated by DCO.
Table 2. Yields of the Liquid Products Obtained in the Single-Step Deoxygenation

div.p: n.d.: not detected.

Figure 2. Product yields in the single-step deoxygenation of (a) palm oil, (b) soybean oil, and (c) linseed oil, calculated with respect to the original mass of the reactant triglycerides (stacked area graph). The white area corresponds to the mass loss due to gaseous products.

div.div:
With time-on-stream, deoxygenation of the three triglycerides showed markedly different deactivation behaviors (
Figure
2
). The yields of the paraffins gradually decreased with the reaction time, the degree of which increased in the order of palm oil < soybean oil < linseed oil. In the case of the palm oil deoxygenation, no significant change in the product distribution was observed up to 180 h (
Figure
2
a). The slightly increased oxygenate formation (
Table
2
), however, indicated a slight deactivation of the catalyst. The liquid products collected during the palm oil deoxygenation contained a very small oxygen content regardless of the reaction time (<0.7 wt %,
Table
3
), indicating almost complete deoxygenation. The effective H/C ratio (H/C
eff
) of the liquid products was always larger than 2, confirming that the saturated hydrocarbons are the dominant products. In contrast, during the deoxygenation of the linseed oil (
Figure
2
c), the yields of
n
-paraffins decreased rapidly within 30 h and then slowly decreased. Meanwhile, the yield of heavy products, undetectable by GC or HPLC, were markedly increased. These compounds are likely to be formed by the oligomerization of polyunsaturated fatty acid units in the linseed oil. The liquid product collected at the initial reaction period (4 h) contained minor content of oxygen (0.6 wt %), but it increased up to 1.2 wt % after 180 h (
Table
3
). In addition, the H/C
eff
ratio decreased from 2.00 to 1.87. The results indicate a substantial catalytic deactivation of the hydrotreating function of Pt/γ-Al
2
O
3
. The reaction with soybean oil showed an intermediate behavior between the palm oil and linseed oil deoxygenations (
Figure
2
b,
Table
2
, and
Table
3
).

Table 3. Elemental Compositions of the Reactant Triglycerides and Their Liquid Deoxygenation Products Collected at 4 and 180 h in Two Different Processes
a

div.p: N and S contents were negligible in all cases.

Effective hydrogen-to-carbon ratio (H/C
eff
) was calculated using the equation, H/C
eff
= {
n
(H) – 2
n
(O) – 3
n
(N) – 2
n
(S)}/
n
(C), where
n
(H),
n
(O),
n
(N),
n
(S), and
n
(C) represent the molar concentrations of H, O, N, S, and C, respectively.

div.div:
Even though it is difficult to analyze the exact molecular structures of the heavy products, information on their molecular size distributions could be analyzed using gel permeation chromatography (GPC,
Figure
3
). Because the oxygen content of the liquid products was always kept low (<1.2 wt %,
Table
3
) compared with those of the reactant triglycerides (10.7–11.7 wt %), it is reasonable to conclude that the heavy products might be produced through the deoxygenation of the oligomeric fatty acid units. To assign the GPC peak positions for the hydrocarbons produced from the monomeric, dimeric, and trimeric fatty acids, heptadecane (C
17
), deoxygenated dimer acid (∼C
34
), and palm oil (∼C
54
) were used as reference materials, respectively (
Figure
3
a). As shown in
Figure
3
b–d, all the liquid products obtained during the deoxygenation of the different triglycerides showed a major peak at 17.6–17.7 min. This is very similar to the peak position of heptadecane (
Figure
3
a), which thus can be assigned to the
n
-paraffins obtained by the deoxygenation of the monomeric fatty acid. In palm oil deoxygenation (
Figure
3
b), only this peak was observed at the initial period of the reaction (4 h) and a very minor peak at 17.0–17.3 min started to be observed after a 60 h reaction. The minor peak could be assigned to the hydrocarbons produced from the dimeric fatty acids (
Figure
3
a). In the deoxygenation of the soybean oil (
Figure
3
c) and linseed oil (
Figure
3
d), the minor peak at 17.0–17.3 min was much more pronounced compared with palm oil deoxygenation and observed even from the initial period of the reaction (4 h). In the case of the linseed oil deoxygenation (
Figure
3
d), the GPC diagrams showed significant tailing even below the retention time of 16.0 min after a 60 h reaction. Considering that the GPC peak of the palm oil (trimeric fatty acids) is observed at 16.4 min, this tailing indicates the formation of even higher oligomers (larger than trimers) of fatty acids. The results imply that the higher unsaturation degrees in fatty acids increased the possibility of oligomerization. The enhanced production of higher oligomers with time-on-stream was attributed to the deactivation of the Pt/γ-Al
2
O
3
catalyst, which could not fully hydrogenate the C═C bonds in the unsaturated fatty acids before their participation in the oligomerization.

div.p: Figure 3. GPC diagrams of (a) reference compounds, and liquid products collected by the single-step deoxygenation of (b) palm oil, (c) soybean oil, and (d) linseed oil at different time-on-streams (4, 60, and 180 h).

div.div:
The oligomeric fatty acids are likely to be formed by the addition of unsaturated fatty acids by Diels–Alder reaction and/or radical addition (
Scheme 3
).
(53−55)
The Diels–Alder reaction between two unsaturated fatty acids requires a double bond rearrangement of the polyunsaturated fatty acids into a conjugated diene system, which is followed by
cis/trans
isomerization. The produced diene can react with an isolated C═C double bond (dienophile) of the other fatty acids to form a cyclic unsaturated structure (
Scheme 3
a). Even though the Diels–Alder reaction can occur thermally, Lewis acids are known to catalyze this reaction by activating the dienophile.
(55,56)
It is known that the dienophile complexed on Lewis acids becomes more electrophilic and more reactive toward the diene. In this regard, it is likely that the abundant Lewis acid sites on the Pt/γ-Al
2
O
3
(170 μmol g
–1
) might catalyze the oligomerization of the unsaturated fatty acids. To confirm the catalytic effects of γ-Al
2
O
3
in oligomerization, we contacted linseed oil onto pure γ-Al
2
O
3
particles at the reaction temperature (653 K) under N
2
atmosphere. For comparison, we did the same experiment using acid-washed quartz particles as an inert material. The collected liquid products were converted to corresponding methyl esters via transesterification with methanol and analyzed using GPC (
Figure S1
). The results showed that even the contact with inert quartz particles could oligomerize the fatty acid units in linseed oil, indicating the presence of noncatalytic thermal oligomerization. However, after the contact with γ-Al
2
O
3
, higher oligomers were formed, indicating that the Lewis acid sites of γ-Al
2
O
3
indeed played a catalytic role in oligomerization. In addition, it is known that radical intermediates can be readily formed by homolytic hydrogen abstraction from the carbon located between two C═C bonds at elevated temperatures.
(53,54)
Such radicals can be added to the C═C bond of other fatty acids, followed by termination by H
•
combination or elimination (
Scheme 3
b).

Scheme 3. Two Possible Oligomerization Pathways for the Polyunsaturated Fatty Acids:
(53)
(a) Diels–Alder Reaction and (b) Radical Addition

The relative rate (defined as the ratio of paraffin yield at
t
and the initial paraffin yield at
t
= 0) as a function of the time-on-stream were fitted using a third-order power-law equation as a deactivation model (
Figure
4
). We tested various power-law models, and the third-order power-law gave the best fitting results (
Figure S2
). In the literature,
(51)
it was proposed that a first-order model fits well for deactivation with no pore diffusion resistance, while higher-order models apply better for deactivation with strong pore diffusion resistance for the reactant (
i.e
., fouling). The present result may imply that the major catalyst deactivation mechanism is fouling rather than active site poisoning. The deactivation rate constant (
k
deac
) increased in the order of palm oil (3.8 × 10
–4
h
–1
) < soybean oil (1.6 × 10
–3
h
–1
) < linseed oil (2.1 × 10
–2
h
–1
). After a reaction for 180 h, the coke contents in the used Pt/γ-Al
2
O
3
were quantified using TGA. The coke amount also increased in the order of palm oil (7.9 wt %) < soybean oil (13.5 wt %) < linseed oil (28.0 wt %). The result indicates that the catalyst deactivation (or the decrease of paraffin yields) was caused by the coke deposition on the catalyst. Because both the coke deposition and the formation of heavy products were enhanced as the degree of unsaturation in the fatty acid units increased, it is reasonable to expect that the coke species might be formed by the subsequent conversion of the heavy products via further polymerization, cyclization, and hydrogen transfer. To further understand the deactivation mechanism, we analyzed the remaining porosity of the catalyst collected after linseed oil conversion for 180 h. The result showed that the pore volume decreased from 0.46 mL g
–1
to almost zero. This result indicated that even N
2
molecules were difficult to access the pores of a deactivated catalyst, which supported that the major deactivation mechanism was fouling. This is consistent with the third-order deactivation kinetics mentioned above.

div.p:
Figure 4. Third-order power-law deactivation fitting of the relative rate (defined as the ratio of paraffin yield at
t
and the initial paraffin yield at
t
= 0) as a function of the time-on-stream in the single-step deoxygenation.

div.div:
In the case of linseed oil deoxygenation, H
2
flow rate was increased 2.5-fold to investigate the effect of different H
2
/triglyceride ratios on catalyst deactivation (
Figure S3
). The result showed that increased hydrogen flow rate could somewhat retard the rate of deactivation. However, substantial catalyst deactivation was still observed (
k
deac
= 1.1 × 10
–2
h
–1
) and heavy compounds were also produced. The result showed that simple modification of reaction conditions in the single-step reaction scheme is not highly efficient for suppressing catalyst deactivation.

As explained above, the deactivation of the Pt/γ-Al
2
O
3
catalyst could be attributed to the coke formation that might be facilitated by the oligomerization of the unsaturated fatty acids. In this regard, we expected that the prehydrogenation of the C═C bonds at low temperatures would be beneficial for suppressing the formation of heavy products as well as catalyst deactivation in deoxygenation. To check this hypothesis, we carried out two-step catalytic deoxygenation in two fixed-bed reactors connected sequentially (
Scheme 2
b). In both reactors, Pt/γ-Al
2
O
3
was used as a catalyst. In the first reactor, prehydrogenation of the triglycerides was carried out at a mild reaction temperature (473 K). In the second reactor, deoxygenation was carried out at 653 K as in the case of the single-step deoxygenation.

After the reaction in the first reactor, the liquid yields were close to 100 wt % for all the reactant triglycerides, indicating the negligible hydrogenolysis of the glyceride backbone at such a mild reaction temperature (473 K). The total yield of the products other than the triglycerides was always less than 1 wt % for all the reactions. The product triglycerides were mainly composed of saturated fatty acids (
Table
4
). Unsaturated fatty acid units were not detected for palm oil, while 0.4 and 4.1 wt % of unsaturated fatty acids were detected for soybean oil and linseed oil, respectively. This result confirms that the first reactor selectively carried out the hydrogenation of C═C bonds in unsaturated fatty acid units while maintaining the original glyceride backbone.
Table 4. Fatty Acid Compositions of Triglycerides Obtained after Prehydrogenation of the Reactant Triglycerides for 90 h

Figure
5
shows the product distributions after the second deoxygenation reactor operated at 653 K. The yields of the heavy products were always kept low (<4 wt %) in all the reactions. For all the reactant triglycerides, a very steady production of
n
-paraffins was observed up to 180 h and the detailed product distributions did not change appreciably during this period (
Table
5
). As shown in
Table
3
, the elemental compositions of liquid products also did not change with reaction time. Up to 180 h, oxygen content lower than 0.7 wt % and H/C
eff
ratio larger than 2 could be steadily achieved for all the triglycerides. The deactivation rate constants (
k
deac
) were very small (
Figure
6
) compared with those observed during the single-step deoxygenation (
Figure
4
). In the case of the linseed oil,
k
deac
in the two-step deoxygenation (3.9 × 10
–4
h
–1
) was 2 orders of magnitude smaller than the
k
deac
in the single-step deoxygenation (2.1 × 10
–2
h
–1
). The coke contents in the used Pt/γ-Al
2
O
3
catalyst of the second deoxygenation reactor were determined as 4.4, 5.8, and 10.2 wt % after the two-step reaction of the palm oil, soybean oil, and linseed oil for 180 h, respectively. These coke amounts were significantly smaller than the coke amounts observed after the single-step deoxygenation (7.9, 13.5, and 28.0 wt % for the palm oil, soybean oil, and linseed oil, respectively). The present results support that the prehydrogenation of triglycerides at a mild temperature (473 K) can markedly retard the formation of heavy products as well as the deactivation of a Pt/γ-Al
2
O
3
catalyst in deoxygenation.
Table 5. Yields of the Liquid Products Obtained in the Two-Step Deoxygenation

div.p: n.d.: not detected.

Figure 5. Product yields in the two-step deoxygenation of (a) palm oil, (b) soybean oil, and (c) linseed oil, calculated with respect to the original mass of the reactant triglycerides (stacked area graph). The white area corresponds to the mass loss due to gaseous products.

Figure 6. Third-order power-law deactivation fitting of the relative rate (defined as the ratio of paraffin yield at
t
and the initial paraffin yield at
t
= 0) as a function of the time-on-stream in the two-step deoxygenation.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The effects of different triglyceride structures on the selectivity and catalyst deactivation were carefully investigated during deoxygenation over a Pt/γ-Al
2
O
3
catalyst. Vegetable oils with different unsaturation degrees (palm oil, soybean oil, and linseed oil) were used as the reactant triglycerides. These oils consisted of fatty acid units with increasing degree of unsaturation in the order of palm oil (average number of C═C per fatty acid: 0.55) < soybean oil (1.33) < linseed oil (2.18). The results show that the increased unsaturation of the triglycerides caused the enhanced formation of heavy products by oligomerization of the unsaturated fatty units by the Diels–Alder reaction and/or radical addition, which can be readily transformed to coke species by hydrogen transfer. In this regard, we showed that prehydrogenation of triglycerides at a mild temperature before the catalytic deoxygenation step is highly beneficial for steadily producing a high yield of diesel-range
n
-paraffins and retarding catalyst deactivation due to coke formation.

A review. Biomass represents an abundant carbon-neutral renewable resource for the prodn. of bioenergy and biomaterials, and its enhanced use would address several societal needs. Advances in genetics, biotechnol., process chem., and engineering are leading to a new manufg. concept for converting renewable biomass to valuable fuels and products, generally referred to as the biorefinery. A review with 38 refs. Diesel fuels derived from triglycerides (vegetable oils/animal fats) present a promising alternative to substitute diesel fuels. Although triglycerides can fuel diesel engines, their high viscosities, low volatilities and poor cold flow properties have led to the investigation of various derivs. Fatty acid Me esters, known as biodiesel, derived from triglycerides by transesterification with methanol have received the most attention. The main advantages of using biodiesel are its renewability, better-quality exhaust gas emissions, its biodegradability and given that all the org. carbon present is photosynthetic in origin, it does not contribute to a rise in the level of carbon dioxide in the atm. and consequently to the greenhouse effect.

Lee, Kyungho; Kim, Myoung Yeob; Choi, Minkee

Ketonization of fatty acids into fatty ketones is a potential route for producing high-value chems. including bioderived lube base oil. In the present work, the catalytic selectivity and deactivation during the ketonization of C18 fatty acids having different unsatn. degrees over a TiO2 catalyst were rigorously investigated. The results demonstrated that the yield of fatty ketone gradually decreased with increasing unsatn. degree, while byproducts such as Me ketones and olefins were produced owing to McLafferty rearrangement. It was verified that carboxylic acids longer than C5 can be decompd. via this pathway, the rate of which increased with the carbon chain length. In the ketonization of unsatd. fatty acids, the McLafferty rearrangement and cracking produced conjugated polyunsatd. olefins (e.g., dienes), which could be readily decompd. to coke. The results implied that the ketonization of natural fatty acids requires the presatn. of C=C bonds for increasing the fatty ketone yield and inhibiting catalyst deactivation. Indeed, the ketonization of a natural fatty acid mixt. obtained by palm oil hydrolysis exhibited diminished fatty ketone selectivity and rapid catalyst deactivation, owing to the presence of unsatd. fatty acids. In contrast, the ketonization of a satd. fatty acid mixt. obtained by hydrogenative hydrolysis exhibited a high fatty ketone yield (∼90%) and negligible deactivation.

Me esters were produced by transesterification of palm oil with methanol in the presence of a catalyst (KOH). The rate of transesterification in a batch reactor increased with temp. up to 60°C. Higher temps. did not reduce the time to reach maximal conversion. The conversion of triglycerides (TG), diglycerides (DG), and monoglycerides (MG) appeared to be second order up to 30 min of reaction time. Reaction rate consts. for TG, DG, and MG hydrolysis reactions were 0.018-0.191 (wt.%-min)-1, and were higher at higher temps. and higher for the MG reaction than for TG hydrolysis. Activation energies were 14.7, 14.2, and 6.4 kcal/mol for the TG, DG, and MG hydrolysis reactions, resp. The optimal catalyst concn. was 1% KOH.

Biodiesel and renewable diesel: A comparison
Knothe, Gerhard

A review. The search for alternatives to petroleum-based fuels has led to the development of fuels from various sources, including renewable feedstocks such as fats and oils. Several types of fuels can be derived from these triacylglycerol-contg. feedstocks. One of them is biodiesel, which is defined as the mono-alkyl esters of vegetable oils or animal fats. Biodiesel is produced by transesterifying the oil or fat with an alc. such as methanol under mild conditions in the presence of a base catalyst. Another kind of product that can be obtained from lipid feedstocks is a fuel whose compn. simulates that of petroleum-derived diesel fuel. This kind of fuel, probably best termed "renewable diesel", is produced from the fat or oil by a hydrodeoxygenation reaction at elevated temp. and pressure in the presence of a catalyst. This article discusses in a general and comparative fashion aspects such as fuel prodn. and energy balance, fuel properties, environmental effects including exhaust emissions and co-products. Among the questions that are addressed are if these fuels compete with or complement each other and what the effect of prodn. scale may be.

The effects of various supported catalysts on the hydroprocessing of soybean oil were studied. Several parameters were taken into account when evaluating the hydroprocessed products, including the conversion, selectivity (naphtha, kero/jet, and diesel), free-fatty acid content, oxygen removal, and satn. of double bonds. The hydroprocessing conversion order was found to be sulfided NiMo/γ-Al2O3 (92.9%) > 4.29 wt.% Pd/γ-Al2O3 (91.9%) > sulfided CoMo/γ-Al2O3 (78.9%) > 57.6 wt.% Ni/SiO2-Al2O3 (60.8%) > 4.95 wt.% Pt/γ-Al2O3 (50.8%) > 3.06 wt.% Ru/Al2O3 (39.7%) at a catalyst/oil wt. ratio of 0.044. The most abundant compn. in the liq. product was straight chain n-C17 and n-C15 alkanes when the Ni or Pd catalysts were used. Enhanced isomerization and cracking reaction activity on the CoMo catalyst may produce lighter and isomerized hydrocarbons. By combining gas-phase and liq. product analyses, decarboxylation was a dominant reaction pathway when the Pd catalyst was used, while hydrodeoxygenation was favored when the NiMo or CoMo catalyst was used.

To produce diesel fuel from renewable org. material such as vegetable oils, it has for a no. of years been known that triglycerides can be hydrogenated into linear alkanes in a refinery hydrotreating unit over conventional sulfided hydrodesulfurization catalysts. A no. of new reactions occur in the hydrotreater, when a biol. component is introduced, and expts. were conducted to obtain a more detailed understanding of these mechanisms. The reaction pathways were studied both in model compd. tests and in real feed tests with mixts. of straight-run gas oil and rapeseed oil. In both sets of expts., the hydrogenation of the O contg. compds. proceeds either via a hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) route or via a decarboxylation route. The detailed pathway of the HDO route was further illuminated by studying the hydroprocessing of Me laurate into n-dodecane. The obsd. reaction intermediates did not support a simple stepwise hydrogenation of the aldehyde formed after hydrogenation of the connecting O in the ester. Instead, probably the aldehyde formed is enolized before further hydrogenation. The existence of an enol intermediate was further corroborated by the observation that a ketone lacking α-H (that cannot be directly enolized) had a much lower reactivity than a corresponding ketone with α-H. In real feed tests, the complete conversion of rapeseed oil into linear alkanes at mild hydrotreating conditions was demonstrated. From the gas and liq. yields, the relative rates of HDO and decarboxylation were calcd. in good agreement with the obsd. distribution of the n-C17/n-C18 and n-C21/n-C22 formed. The H consumption assocd. with each route is deduced, and H consumed in the H2O-gas-shift and methanization reactions may add significant H consumption to the decarboxylation route. The products formed exhibited high cetane values and low densities. The challenges of introducing triglycerides in conventional hydrotreating units are discussed. Hydrotreating offers a robust and flexible process for converting a wide variety of alternative feedstocks into a green diesel fuel that is directly compatible with existing fuel infrastructure and engine technol.

Hydroprocessing of neat sunflower oil was carried out at 360-420 °C and 18 MPa over a com. hydrocracking catalyst in a bench scale fixed bed reactor. In the studied exptl. range, products consisted exclusively of hydrocarbons that differed significantly in compn. While the concn. of n-alkanes exceeded 67 wt.% in the reaction products collected at 360 °C, it decreased to just 20 wt.% in the product obtained at 420 °C. Consequently, the fuel properties of the latter product were very similar to those of std. (petroleum-derived) diesel fuel. Particularly, it exhibited excellent low-temp. properties (cloud point -11 °C; CFPP -14 °C). Reaction products obtained at 400 and 420 °C were blended into petroleum-derived diesel fuel in three concn. levels ranging from 10 to 50 wt.% and the fuel properties of these mixts. were evaluated. Diesel fuel mixts. contg. the product of sunflower oil hydrocracking at 420 °C showed very good low-temp. properties including cloud point (-8 °C) and CFPP (-15 °C) that was further lowered to -25 °C due to addn. of flow improvers.

Maximizing Biojet Fuel Production from Triglyceride: Importance of the Hydrocracking Catalyst and Separate Deoxygenation/Hydrocracking Steps
Kim, Myoung Yeob; Kim, Jae-Kon; Lee, Mi-Eun; Lee, Songhyun; Choi, Minkee
ACS Catalysis

Various parameters in the catalytic hydroconversion of triglycerides (palm oil) were carefully investigated for maximizing the prodn. of biojet fuel. The results showed that the deoxygenation of triglyceride via hydrotreatment should be carried out in a sep. reactor prior to the hydrocracking step (i.e., two-step reaction process). Otherwise, the CO generated during deoxygenation can poison the metal components in the metal/acid bifunctional catalysts (Pt/zeolites), which can cause significant imbalance between the metal and acid functions in hydrocracking. This leads to fast catalyst deactivation via coke formation, heavy formation of aroms., and overcracking of hydrocarbons, resulting in the redn. of final biojet fuel yield. In the two-step process, the second hydrocracking step mainly dets. the final biojet fuel yield, and thus, a rational design of the hydrocracking catalysts that can suppress overcracking is essential. The diffusion characteristics of the multibranched hydrocarbon (e.g., 2,2,4-trimethylpentane) in the hydrocracking catalysts could be correlated with the yields of the jet fuel-range C8-C16 hydrocarbons and the iso/n-paraffin ratios. The result indicates that the facile diffusion of multibranched isomers out of catalysts before excessive cracking is important for the suppression of the formation of light hydrocarbons (≤C7). Consequently, Pt supported on nanocryst. large-pore BEA zeolite showed the largest biojet fuel yield with the highest iso-paraffin content. Under the optimized conditions, 55 wt % of biojet fuel with respect to palm oil was achieved after final distn., which satisfied all the required fuel specifications.

Alternative fuels are expected to play a major role in EU in the coming years due European Directives on the promotion of renewable energies and redn. of greenhouse gas emissions in transports. However, while in road transports a variety of possible renewable fuels (mainly biofuels, but also electricity) can be considered, in aviation only high quality paraffinic biofuels can be adopted. This means that biomass must be converted through advanced processes into pure hydrocarbon fuels, fully compatible with the existing systems. The aviation sector is responsible for the 2% of the world anthropogenic CO2 emissions and the 10% of the fuel consumption: airlines' costs for fuel reach 30% of operating costs. In addn., the aviation traffic is expected to double within 15 years from 2012, while fuel consumption and CO2 emissions should double in 25 years. Thus, more than 2 billion people and 40 Mt of good/cargo will have to be moved every year. In this context, the EU Flightpath set a target of 2 Mt per yr for aviation alternative fuel by 2020 (i.e. 4% of annual fuel consumption). New processes towards bio-hydrocarbons are being developed, demonstrated and soon industrialized.The present work explores the possible routes from biomass feedstock to sustainable paraffinic fuels, either through bio or thermo-chem. processes, as well as discusses those more mature, focusing on industrial demonstration initiatives. In fact, while the no. of possible options towards paraffinic biofuel prodn. is very large, and covers both thermochem. and biochem. routes, as well as hybrid one, only two pathways are today ready for testing a significant large scale: these are FT and Hydrotreating. Major industrial activities and testing experiences are thus reported in the present work.In this context, the ITAKA group is developing a full value-chain in Europe to produce sustainable drop-in Synthetic Paraffinic Kerosene (SPK) - called HEFA - in an economically, socially and environmentally sound manner, at large scale enough to allow testing its use in existing logistic systems and in normal flight operations in Europe. The generated knowledge will aim to identify and address barriers to innovation. Within ITAKA, possible pre-processing of used (waste) cooking oil (UCO) to make it compatible with current downstream hydroprocessing techniques are being investigated: this can includes esterification of waste oils, as well as catalytic thermal processing, which will be carried out in a pilot unit available at RE-CORD/CREAR. First samples of feedstock oils were collected and characterized, for further investigation towards their conversion into biokerosene through hydrotreatment.

Biomass-derived jet (bio-jet) fuel has become a key element in the aviation industry's strategy to reduce operating costs and environmental impacts. Researchers from the oil-refining industry, the aviation industry, government, biofuel companies, agricultural organizations, and academia are working toward developing a com. viable and sustainable process that produces a long-lasting renewable jet fuel with low prodn. costs and low greenhouse emissions. This jet fuel, addnl., must meet ASTM International specifications and potentially be a 100% drop-in replacement for current petroleum jet fuel. In this study, the current technologies for producing renewable jet fuels, categorized by alcs.-to-jet, oil-to-jet, syngas-to-jet, and sugar-to-jet pathways are reviewed. The main challenges for each technol. pathway, including conceptual process design, process economics and life-cycle assessment of greenhouse gas emissions are discussed. Although the feedstock price and availability and energy intensity of the process are significant barriers, biomass-derived jet fuel has the potential to replace a significant portion of conventional jet fuel required to meet com. and military demand.

There is interest in the prodn. of fuels from triglycerides of biol. origin. Tricaprylin (TC) and caprylic acid (CA) were used as model compds. to study the catalytic hydroconversion of triglycerides to acyclic aliph. hydrocarbons. Supported metal and metal oxide catalysts, Pd on activated C (Pd/C), and Ni-promoted molybdenum on alumina (Ni,Mo/γ-Al2O3) were used. The reaction proceeds in consecutive steps: hydrogenolysis of TC to CA and propane, followed by hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of the CA intermediate. The overall reaction rate was governed by the rate of the HDO reaction. Two HDO routes were distinguished: (a) hydrodecabonylation and (b) redn. of O. Over Pd/C the prevailing reaction route of CA hydroconversion was the decarbonylation giving mainly C7 alkane and CO, whereas the HDO over the Ni,Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts proceeded in consecutive H2 addn. and dehydration steps giving predominantly C8 alkenes, C8 alkanes and H2O. In reaction route (b) alc. and traces of aldehyde were detected as acid-to-alkane intermediates. Probably reaction route (a) occurs via a formic acid intermediate that, in the presence of H2, rapidly decomps. to CO and H2O.

Deoxygenation of fatty acids (oleic and stearic acids) and non-edible oil (jatropha oil) over Pd(1-5 wt%) supported on two structurally different, three-dimensional, mesoporous silica (SBA-12 and SBA-16) catalysts was investigated. Pd/SBA-16 (cubic mesoporous structure with space group Im‾3m) showed higher catalytic activity than Pd/SBA-12 (hexagonal mesoporous structure with space group p63/mmc). The influence of reaction parameters like temp., H2 pressure and Pd content as well as the nature of the feedstock on catalytic activity and product selectivity was studied. A temp. of above 320°C, reaction time of 5 h and Pd content (on silica surface) of 3 wt% enabled complete conversion of the fatty compds. into diesel-range hydrocarbons. Deoxygenation proceeded through hydrodeoxygenation and decarboxylation mechanisms when a satd. (stearic) acid was used as a feed while it advanced mainly through decarboxylation route when an unsatd. (oleic) acid was employed. Higher surface hydrophobicity and smaller size particles of Pd are the possible causes for the superior catalytic activity of Pd/SBA-16.

Hydrodeoxygenation of waste fats and oils is a viable method for producing renewable diesel oil. In this study a model feed consisting of oleic acid and tripalmitin in molar ratio 1:3 was hydrotreated at 325 °C with 20 bars H2 in a stirred batch autoclave with a 5 wt% Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, and samples were extd. periodically and analyzed on GC. Despite the significant hydrogen pressure hydrogenation of both reactants were limited and decarboxylation or decarbonylation of the ester and carboxylic acid functionalities were highly favored, yielding carbon chain lengths of odd nos. Moreover, Pd/γ-Al2O3 was obsd. to be slightly more active than Pt/γ-Al2O3 and had a higher ratio of decarboxylation and decarbonylation to hydrogenation, while Ni/γ-Al2O3 was substantially less active than Pt and also showed a markedly lower ratio of decarboxylation and decarbonylation to hydrogenation. Variation of the temp. showed that triglycerides as well as free fatty acids were converted at all investigated temps., but the conversion of oleic acid increased from 6% to 100% when the temp. was increased from 250 °C to 325 °C. The tripalmitin reacted via a palmitic acid intermediate, and its conversion was limited by formation of this free fatty acid.

Deoxygenation of vegetable oils can become an important process for prodn. of biofuels. Ni, Mo and NiMo sulfided catalysts, prepd. by impregnation in deoxygenation of rapeseed oil at 260-280°, 3.5 MPa and 0.25-4 h-1 in a fixed-bed reactor, were studied. The activity of the catalysts decreased in the order NiMo/Al2O3 > Mo/Al2O3 > Ni/Al2O3. The catalysts exhibited different product distributions. The bimetallic NiMo catalysts showed higher yields of hydrocarbons than the monometallic catalysts at a given conversion. Apart from the various oxygenated product intermediates, NiMo/Al2O3 yielded a mixt. of decarboxylation and hydrodeoxygenation hydrocarbon products but Ni/Al2O3 yielded only decarboxylation hydrocarbon products and Mo/Al2O3 yielded almost exclusively hydrodeoxygenation hydrocarbon products. The effect of Ni/(Ni+Mo) at. ratio in the range 0.2-0.4 on the activity and selectivity was not significant.

The deoxygenation of waste chicken fat contg. a high degree of free fatty acids (FFAs) and water has been implemented to produce a green diesel, known as biohydrogenated diesel (BHD). The effect of the water and free fatty acid content in the chicken fat on the conversion, BHD yield, and liq./gas product distribution was investigated over a Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in a trickle-bed reactor. The major reaction pathway was decarbonylation/decarboxylation (DCO/DCO2), whereas hydrodeoxygenation was minor. Methane from methanation of the resultant CO/CO2 and propane cracking was a major gaseous product. The FFA and water content improved the BHD yield and the overall contribution of the DCO/DCO2. The presence of water accelerated the breakdown of the triglyceride mols. into FFAs. Therefore, waste chicken fat from food industries contg. a high degree of FFAs and water content can be used as a low-cost feedstock for renewable diesel prodn. without requirement of a pretreatment process.

Reaction Pathways for the Deoxygenation of Vegetable Oils and Related Model Compounds
Gosselink, Robert W.; Hollak, Stefan A. W.; Chang, Shu-Wei; van Haveren, Jacco; de Jong, Krijn P.; Bitter, Johannes H.; van Es, Daan S.
ChemSusChem
(
2013

(
9

; ISSN:
1864-5631
.
(
Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA
)
A review. Vegetable oil-based feeds are regarded as an alternative source for the prodn. of fuels and chems. Paraffins and olefins can be produced from these feeds through catalytic deoxygenation. The fundamentals of this process are mostly studied by using model compds. such as fatty acids, fatty acid esters, and specific triglycerides because of their structural similarity to vegetable oils. In this review the impact of feedstock, reaction conditions, and nature of the catalyst on the reaction pathways of the deoxygenation of vegetable oils and its derivs. are discussed. As such, the authors conclude on the suitability of model compds. for this reaction. The type of catalyst has a significant effect on the deoxygenation pathway, i.e., Group 10 metal catalysts are active in decarbonylation/decarboxylation whereas metal sulfide catalysts are more selective to hydrodeoxygenation. Deoxygenation studies performed under H2 showed similar pathways for fatty acids, fatty acid esters, triglycerides, and vegetable oils, as mostly deoxygenation occurs indirectly via the formation of fatty acids. Deoxygenation in the absence of H2 results in significant differences in reaction pathways and selectivities depending on the feedstock. Addnl., using unsatd. feedstock under inert gas results in a high selectivity to undesired reactions such as cracking and the formation of heavies. Therefore, addn. of H2 probably is essential for the catalytic deoxygenation of vegetable oil feeds.

The deoxygenation of palmitic and lauric acids over 0.5 wt % Pt/ZIF-67 membrane/zeolite 5A bead catalysts is demonstrated. Almost complete conversion (% deoxygenation of ≥95%) of these two fatty acids was obsd. over both fresh and recycled catalyst after a 2 h reaction time. The catalysts displayed high selectivity to pentadecane and undecane via decarboxylation reaction pathway even at low 0.5 wt % Pt loading. Selectivity to pentadecane and undecane as high as ∼92% and ∼94% was obsd. under CO2 atmosphere when palmitic and lauric acids were used resp. as reactants. Depending on the reaction gas atm., two distinctive reaction pathways were obsd.: decarboxylation and hydrodeoxygenation. Specifically, it was found that decarboxylation reaction pathway was more favorable in the presence of helium and CO2, while hydrodeoxygenation pathway strongly competed against the decarboxylation pathway when hydrogen was employed during the deoxygenation reactions. Esters were identified as the key reaction intermediates leading to decarboxylation and hydrodeoxygenation pathways.

Various supported metal catalysts are screened for hydrogenation of lauric acid and 2-octanone as model reactions for the transformation of biomass-derived oxygenates to liq. alkanes (biofuels) in a batch reactor under solvent-free conditions. Among the catalysts tested, Pt and MoOx co-loaded on TiO2 (Pt-MoOx/TiO2) shows the highest yields of n-alkanes for both of the reactions. Pt-MoOx/TiO2 selectively catalyzes the hydrodeoxygenation of various fatty acids and triglycerides to n-alkanes without C-C bond cleavage under 50 bar H2 and shows higher turnover nos. than the catalysts in the literature. Pt-MoOx/TiO2 is effective also for the hydrodeoxygenation of various ketones to the corresponding alkanes. In situ IR study of the reaction of adsorbed acetone under H2 suggests that the high activity of Pt-MoOx/TiO2 is attributed to the cooperation between Pt and Lewis acid sites of the MoOx/TiO2 support.

The conversion of Me octanoate on an H-ZSM5 zeolite catalyst was studied as a model reaction for the prodn. of hydrocarbon fuels and chems. from biodiesel. The reactivity of Me octanoate on H-ZSM5 is higher than that obsd. with a linear alkane of the same chain length as the ester, n-octane. The enhanced activity may be due to the strong adsorption of the ester group on the zeolite sites. The deoxygenation of Me octanoate yielded a variety of hydrocarbons (C1-C7), with significant amts. of aroms. Octanoic acid and heavy products, particularly 8-pentadecanone, were formed as primary products from Me octanoate via acid-catalyzed hydrolysis and condensation, resp. Both octanoic acid and the condensation products undergo further reaction, producing aroms. The comparison conducted with n-octane as a feed indicates that aroms. can be formed through a series of reactions, namely cracking, oligomerization, and cyclization. A small amt. of ethylbenzene and o-xylene at low conversion of Me octanoate indicates that direct dehydrocyclization may also take place, but this path was not evident when the feed was n-octane.

In hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) on sulfided hydrotreating catalysts, addn. of a sulfiding agent is typically required to maintain the catalyst activity. The effects of H2S and CS2 on the HDO of aliph. esters on sulfided NiMo/γ-Al2O3 and CoMo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were studied in a fixed-bed flow reactor. The model compds. studied were Me heptanoate, Et heptanoate, heptanol and heptanoic acid. The HDO produced C7 and C6 hydrocarbons in reactions where oxygen- and sulfur-contg. compds. were formed as intermediates. Unlike CS2, H2S had a promoting effect on the HDO of the aliph. oxygenates. The addn. of H2S stabilized the selectivities as a function of time, and shifted the main products from C7 to C6 hydrocarbons, but did not prevent catalyst deactivation. The promoting effect of H2S was attributed to the increased catalyst acidity, which enhanced the acid-catalyzed reactions (hydrolysis, esterification, dehydration, E2 elimination and SN2 nucleophilic substitution). Both H2S and CS2 suppressed the hydrogenation reactions on the NiMo catalyst but did not affect them significantly on the CoMo catalyst. H2S induced less hydrogen consumption and coke formation than CS2, but the carbon efficiency suffered in the presence of H2S. Thus, the use of H2S as sulfiding agent in the HDO of the aliph. oxygenates is more beneficial than the use of CS2.

Wood-derived bio-oil contains high amts. of compds. with different oxygen-contg. functional groups that must be removed to improve the fuel characteristics. Elimination of oxygen from carboxylic groups was studied with model compds., Me heptanoate and Me hexanoate, on sulfided NiMo/γ-Al2O3 and CoMo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts in a flow reactor. Catalyst performances and reaction schemes were addressed. Aliph. Me esters produced hydrocarbons via three main paths: The 1st path gave alcs. followed by dehydration to hydrocarbons. Deesterification yielded an alc. and a carboxylic acid in the 2nd path. Carboxylic acid was further converted to hydrocarbons either directly or with an alc. intermediate. Decarboxylation of the esters led to hydrocarbons in the 3rd path. No oxygen-contg. compds. were detected at complete conversions. However, the product distributions changed with time, even at complete conversions, indicating that both catalysts deactivated under the studied conditions.

Catalytic deoxygenation of tall oil fatty acids (TOFAs) was investigated over 1 wt % Pd/C Sibunit, which is a synthetic mesoporous carbon. The reactions were performed in a semi-batch reactor using dodecane as a solvent under 17 bar of total pressure. The main studied parameters were the reaction temp., initial concn. of TOFA, effect of the reaction atm., and metal loading. The temp. and initial concn. ranges were 300-350 °C and 0.15-0.6 mol/L, resp. The total conversion of fatty acids increased, as expected, with increasing temps. and decreasing initial TOFA concns. The main liq.-phase products were n-heptadecane and n-heptadecene. In addn. to the desired linear C17 hydrocarbons, also arom. C17 compds., such as undecylbenzene, were formed. The best conditions for the formation of the desired C17 hydrocarbons were lower initial concns. of TOFA, 300-325 °C, and the presence of hydrogen. An increase of the metal loading (4 wt %) led to an increase of the selectivity to linear C17 hydrocarbons.

Mercaptosilane-Assisted Synthesis of Metal Clusters within Zeolites and Catalytic Consequences of Encapsulation
Choi, Minkee; Wu, Zhijie; Iglesia, Enrique

The authors report here a general synthetic strategy to encapsulate metal clusters within zeolites during their hydrothermal crystn. Precursors to metal clusters are stabilized against their premature colloidal pptn. as hydroxides during zeolite crystn. using bifunctional (3-mercaptopropyl)trimethoxysilane ligands. Mercapto (-SH) groups in these ligands interact with cationic metal centers, while alkoxysilane moieties form covalent Si-O-Si or Si-O-Al linkages that promote zeolite nucleation around ligated metal precursors. These protocols led to the successful encapsulation of Pt, Pd, Ir, Rh, and Ag clusters within the NaA zeolite, for which small channel apertures (0.41 nm) preclude post-synthesis deposition of metal clusters. Sequential treatments in O2 and H2 formed small (∼1 nm) clusters with uniform diam. Titrn. of exposed atoms with H2 or O2 gave metal dispersions that agree well with mean cluster sizes measured from electron microscopy and x-ray absorption spectroscopy, consistent with accessible cluster surfaces free of mercaptosilane residues. NaA micropore apertures restrict access to encapsulated clusters by reactants based on their mol. size. The ratio of the rates of hydrogenation of ethene and isobutene is much higher on clusters encapsulated within NaA than those dispersed on SiO2, as also found for the relative rates of MeOH and isobutanol oxidn. These data confirm the high encapsulation selectivity achieved by these synthetic protocols and the ability of NaA micropores to sieve reactants based on mol. size. Containment within small micropores also protects clusters against thermal sintering and prevents poisoning of active sites by organosulfur species, thus allowing alkene hydrogenation to persist even in the presence of thiophene. The bifunctional nature and remarkable specificity of the mercapto and alkoxysilane functions for metal and zeolite precursors, resp., render these protocols extendable to diverse metal-zeolite systems useful as shape-selective catalysts in demanding chem. environments.

Integrated molar extinction coeffs. were detd. for IR absorption bands of pyridine adsorbed on acid sites in Si/Al-based catalysts. The IR spectra of five zeolites and two amorphous silica-aluminas were recorded during quant. dosing of pyridine gas at 150°. The integrated mol. extinction coeffs. were calcd. assuming that they did not depend on the catalyst or the strength of the acid site. The resulting values were 1.67 cm/μmol for the 1545-cm-1 band characteristic of pyridine on a Broensted acid site and 2.22 cm/μmol for the 1455-cm-1 band of pyridine on a Lewis acid site. The 95% confidence limits were estd. at ±15%. Subsequent anal. of the data provided no evidence for a dependence of the integrated coeffs. on the catalyst or the strength of the site. The measurements gave indications for differences between the rates of reaction of Broensted and Lewis acid sites with pyridine.

Wheat flour lipids present a complex mixt. of components with varying polarities and have been classified as either starch or non-starch lipids, the latter being further subdivided in free and bound lipids depending on the extn. method and solvents used. A novel sepn. and detection method for wheat lipids in flour and dough that separates both non-polar and polar lipid classes in a single run HPLC anal. using a monolithic silica column and a quaternary gradient and detects them with evaporative light scattering is presented. The method was applied to study in-depth the changes in lipid distribution during bread dough development, thereby monitoring the fate of the different lipid classes. Full dough development was not necessary to decrease the extractability of both non-polar and polar free lipids and increase their levels in the bound lipid ext. The data for the first time also showed which specific lipid classes were redistributed and transferred from starch to gluten, as confirmed by analyzing starch fractions. In addn., not all redistributed lipids interacted in a similar way with the gluten proteins. Major changes occurred during the first 30 s of mixing after which slight changes were obsd. for triacylglycerols, free fatty acids, lysophosphatidylcholine, and N-acylphosphatidylethanolamine.

Product distributions in bio-crude, aq. phase, and solid residue were rigorously analyzed during the hydrothermal liquefaction (HTL) of Chlorella sp. KR1 in order to optimize utilization of energy and chems. A non-asphaltene (paraffinic) fraction in the bio-crude, which can be readily upgraded to high-quality fuels via a subsequent catalytic process, was mainly produced due to lipid extn. Above 170 °C, lipid extn. was almost complete, and hence, the non-asphaltene content did not increase further with increasing temp. Carbohydrates could be extd., mainly as polysaccharides, in the aq. phase at mild temps. (<200 °C). At high temps. (>200 °C), they decomp. and react with proteins via the Maillard reaction to form asphaltene (polycyclic aroms.), which contains large amts. of heteroatoms such as N and S. Although high-temp. carbohydrate conversion could yield more bio-crude with high energy values, it dominantly contributed to formation of the asphaltene fraction, which is difficult to upgrade catalytically. As high-temp. HTL requires a large energy input, the recovery and utilization of intact carbohydrates and proteins at mild temps. (<200 °C) appears to be more promising. Energy Return on Investment (EROI) anal. also showed that 170 °C is the optimum HTL temp. for maximizing the energy prodn.

Catalytic reaction pathways in liquid-phase deoxygenation of C18 free fatty acids
Immer, Jeremy G.; Kelly, M. Jason; Lamb, H. Henry
Applied Catalysis, A: General
(

),

(

The liq.-phase deoxygenation of stearic, oleic, and linoleic acids employing a 5 wt% Pd/C catalyst was investigated using online quadrupole mass spectrometry (QMS). Catalytic deoxygenation of stearic acid (SA) under He occurs primarily via decarboxylation; the liq. products are n-heptadecane and heptadecenes. Online QMS revealed concomitant CO2 and H2 evolution which can explain the greater than expected heptadecene yields at low to intermediate conversions. After essentially complete SA conversion, hydrogenation of heptadecenes via hydrogen transfer from the dodecane solvent results in 98% n-heptadecane yield. The initial rate of SA decarboxylation under 10% H2 is lower than under He; however, by avoiding the formation of unsatd. products the reaction requires much less time to reach completion. The SA decarboxylation rate under 10% H2 is 6-fold slower in heptadecane than in dodecane. This apparent solvent effect is explained by the lower vapor pressure of heptadecane resulting in greater H2 inhibition of the decarboxylation reaction. Our results demonstrate that the unsatd. C18 free fatty acids, oleic and linoleic, must be hydrogenated to SA before decarboxylation can proceed at a significant rate. Oleic acid (OA) deoxygenation under He occurs very slowly and primarily via decarbonylation. In contrast, OA deoxygenation under 10% H2 occurs facilely via hydrogenation to SA followed by decarboxylation. Since hydrogenation is complete during heating to reaction temp., the decarboxylation kinetics and product yields are not affected by the initial unsatn. of the reactant.

Several theories have been proposed concerning the stand oil reaction but no precise reaction scheme has been described. In this work, the stand reaction of linseed oil was characterized in order to det. the nature of the products formed during this reaction. Using complementary anal. techniques (more esp. NMR and mass spectrometry), the existence of two different reactions was demonstrated: the Diels-Alder addn. between fatty acid chains and the addn. of a methylene radical on double bonds, followed by combination or elimination reactions.

A review. Biomass represents an abundant carbon-neutral renewable resource for the prodn. of bioenergy and biomaterials, and its enhanced use would address several societal needs. Advances in genetics, biotechnol., process chem., and engineering are leading to a new manufg. concept for converting renewable biomass to valuable fuels and products, generally referred to as the biorefinery. The integration of agro-energy crops and biorefinery manufg. technologies offers the potential for the development of sustainable bio-power and biomaterials that will lead to a new manufg. paradigm.

A review of chem. catalytic transformation of biomass-derived oxygenated feedstock (primarily sugars and sugar-alcs.) in the liq. phase to value-added chems. and fuels, with examples emphasizing the development of catalytic processes based on an understanding of the fundamental reaction chem. Biomass can be a sustainable source of energy and org. C for the industrialized society. The key reactions involved in the processing of biomass are hydrolysis, dehydration, isomerization, aldol condensation, reforming, hydrogenation, and oxidn. Is discussed how ideas based on fundamental chem. and catalytic concepts lead to strategies for the control of reaction pathways and process conditions to produce H2/CO2 or H2/CO gas mixts. by aq.-phase reforming, to produce furan compds. by selective dehydration of carbohydrates, and to produce liq. alkanes by the combination of aldol condensation and dehydration/hydrogenation processes.

A review with 38 refs. Diesel fuels derived from triglycerides (vegetable oils/animal fats) present a promising alternative to substitute diesel fuels. Although triglycerides can fuel diesel engines, their high viscosities, low volatilities and poor cold flow properties have led to the investigation of various derivs. Fatty acid Me esters, known as biodiesel, derived from triglycerides by transesterification with methanol have received the most attention. The main advantages of using biodiesel are its renewability, better-quality exhaust gas emissions, its biodegradability and given that all the org. carbon present is photosynthetic in origin, it does not contribute to a rise in the level of carbon dioxide in the atm. and consequently to the greenhouse effect.

Ketonization of fatty acids into fatty ketones is a potential route for producing high-value chems. including bioderived lube base oil. In the present work, the catalytic selectivity and deactivation during the ketonization of C18 fatty acids having different unsatn. degrees over a TiO2 catalyst were rigorously investigated. The results demonstrated that the yield of fatty ketone gradually decreased with increasing unsatn. degree, while byproducts such as Me ketones and olefins were produced owing to McLafferty rearrangement. It was verified that carboxylic acids longer than C5 can be decompd. via this pathway, the rate of which increased with the carbon chain length. In the ketonization of unsatd. fatty acids, the McLafferty rearrangement and cracking produced conjugated polyunsatd. olefins (e.g., dienes), which could be readily decompd. to coke. The results implied that the ketonization of natural fatty acids requires the presatn. of C=C bonds for increasing the fatty ketone yield and inhibiting catalyst deactivation. Indeed, the ketonization of a natural fatty acid mixt. obtained by palm oil hydrolysis exhibited diminished fatty ketone selectivity and rapid catalyst deactivation, owing to the presence of unsatd. fatty acids. In contrast, the ketonization of a satd. fatty acid mixt. obtained by hydrogenative hydrolysis exhibited a high fatty ketone yield (∼90%) and negligible deactivation.

Me esters were produced by transesterification of palm oil with methanol in the presence of a catalyst (KOH). The rate of transesterification in a batch reactor increased with temp. up to 60°C. Higher temps. did not reduce the time to reach maximal conversion. The conversion of triglycerides (TG), diglycerides (DG), and monoglycerides (MG) appeared to be second order up to 30 min of reaction time. Reaction rate consts. for TG, DG, and MG hydrolysis reactions were 0.018-0.191 (wt.%-min)-1, and were higher at higher temps. and higher for the MG reaction than for TG hydrolysis. Activation energies were 14.7, 14.2, and 6.4 kcal/mol for the TG, DG, and MG hydrolysis reactions, resp. The optimal catalyst concn. was 1% KOH.

A review. The search for alternatives to petroleum-based fuels has led to the development of fuels from various sources, including renewable feedstocks such as fats and oils. Several types of fuels can be derived from these triacylglycerol-contg. feedstocks. One of them is biodiesel, which is defined as the mono-alkyl esters of vegetable oils or animal fats. Biodiesel is produced by transesterifying the oil or fat with an alc. such as methanol under mild conditions in the presence of a base catalyst. Another kind of product that can be obtained from lipid feedstocks is a fuel whose compn. simulates that of petroleum-derived diesel fuel. This kind of fuel, probably best termed "renewable diesel", is produced from the fat or oil by a hydrodeoxygenation reaction at elevated temp. and pressure in the presence of a catalyst. This article discusses in a general and comparative fashion aspects such as fuel prodn. and energy balance, fuel properties, environmental effects including exhaust emissions and co-products. Among the questions that are addressed are if these fuels compete with or complement each other and what the effect of prodn. scale may be.

The effects of various supported catalysts on the hydroprocessing of soybean oil were studied. Several parameters were taken into account when evaluating the hydroprocessed products, including the conversion, selectivity (naphtha, kero/jet, and diesel), free-fatty acid content, oxygen removal, and satn. of double bonds. The hydroprocessing conversion order was found to be sulfided NiMo/γ-Al2O3 (92.9%) > 4.29 wt.% Pd/γ-Al2O3 (91.9%) > sulfided CoMo/γ-Al2O3 (78.9%) > 57.6 wt.% Ni/SiO2-Al2O3 (60.8%) > 4.95 wt.% Pt/γ-Al2O3 (50.8%) > 3.06 wt.% Ru/Al2O3 (39.7%) at a catalyst/oil wt. ratio of 0.044. The most abundant compn. in the liq. product was straight chain n-C17 and n-C15 alkanes when the Ni or Pd catalysts were used. Enhanced isomerization and cracking reaction activity on the CoMo catalyst may produce lighter and isomerized hydrocarbons. By combining gas-phase and liq. product analyses, decarboxylation was a dominant reaction pathway when the Pd catalyst was used, while hydrodeoxygenation was favored when the NiMo or CoMo catalyst was used.

To produce diesel fuel from renewable org. material such as vegetable oils, it has for a no. of years been known that triglycerides can be hydrogenated into linear alkanes in a refinery hydrotreating unit over conventional sulfided hydrodesulfurization catalysts. A no. of new reactions occur in the hydrotreater, when a biol. component is introduced, and expts. were conducted to obtain a more detailed understanding of these mechanisms. The reaction pathways were studied both in model compd. tests and in real feed tests with mixts. of straight-run gas oil and rapeseed oil. In both sets of expts., the hydrogenation of the O contg. compds. proceeds either via a hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) route or via a decarboxylation route. The detailed pathway of the HDO route was further illuminated by studying the hydroprocessing of Me laurate into n-dodecane. The obsd. reaction intermediates did not support a simple stepwise hydrogenation of the aldehyde formed after hydrogenation of the connecting O in the ester. Instead, probably the aldehyde formed is enolized before further hydrogenation. The existence of an enol intermediate was further corroborated by the observation that a ketone lacking α-H (that cannot be directly enolized) had a much lower reactivity than a corresponding ketone with α-H. In real feed tests, the complete conversion of rapeseed oil into linear alkanes at mild hydrotreating conditions was demonstrated. From the gas and liq. yields, the relative rates of HDO and decarboxylation were calcd. in good agreement with the obsd. distribution of the n-C17/n-C18 and n-C21/n-C22 formed. The H consumption assocd. with each route is deduced, and H consumed in the H2O-gas-shift and methanization reactions may add significant H consumption to the decarboxylation route. The products formed exhibited high cetane values and low densities. The challenges of introducing triglycerides in conventional hydrotreating units are discussed. Hydrotreating offers a robust and flexible process for converting a wide variety of alternative feedstocks into a green diesel fuel that is directly compatible with existing fuel infrastructure and engine technol.
